title: Melanocortin
text:
The melanocortins are a group of <a href="peptide%20hormone">peptide hormone</a>s which include <a href="adrenocorticotropic%20hormone">adrenocorticotropic hormone</a> (ACTH) and the different forms of <a href="melanocyte-stimulating%20hormone">melanocyte-stimulating hormone</a> (MSH), and are derived from <a href="proopiomelanocortin">proopiomelanocortin</a> (POMC) in the <a href="pituitary%20gland">pituitary gland</a>. The melanocortins exert their effects by binding to and activating the <a href="melanocortin%20receptor">melanocortin receptor</a>s. 
There are 5 melanocortin receptors (MCR) and all of them are <a href="G%20protein%E2%80%93coupled%20receptor">G protein–coupled receptor</a>s. In the brain, only MC3R and MC4R are expressed and their endogenous ligand is α-MSH. <a href="Agouti-related%20peptide">Agouti-related peptide</a> (AgRP) is the endogenous antagonist. 
Function.
The melanocortin system is one of the mammalian body's tools to regulate food intake in a push-pull fashion. The only neurons known to release melanocortins are located in the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus. Accordingly, there is a subpopulation called POMC neurons and one called AgRP neurons. When POMC neurons release α-MSH, appetite is decreased. On the other hand, when AgRP neurons release AgRP, appetite is stimulated. 
<a href="Leptin">Leptin</a>, the energy surfeit hormone, and <a href="Ghrelin">Ghrelin</a>, the hunger hormone, are upstream regulators of the melanocortin system in the brain. These hormones also regulate the release of peptides other than the melanocortins. Disturbance of the leptin-melanocortin pathway can lead to early onset obesity as well as various metabolic disorders and suppressed immune function.
